list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The diagram below shows a car of mass $m$ descending a slope. The car, initially at rest, covers a distance of 27 m in 3.0 s.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b5634a7-bfb0-4c45-859f-2684b781580b/images/3d546597-f800-49ad-b760-e4ace00a2c04/PH0123.png)


The magnitude of the acceleration is given by


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 3.0 m s$^{-2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 6.0 m s$^{-2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 9.0 m s$^{-2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 81 m s$^{-2}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From the equation of motion


- $ s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$

initially the velocity, $u$ is zero giving


- $a = \dfrac{\textrm{2 s}}{t^2} \hspace{1em}$

Substituting $t = 3$ s:


- $a=\dfrac{\textrm{(2)(27.0 m)}}{(3.0\ \ce{s})^2} = 6.0$ m s$^{-2}$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
An object moves at constant velocity for a period of time, after which it undergoes uniform deceleration until it comes to rest. A velocity-time graph is plotted for this motion. On the graph, which of the following would represent the displacement of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Gradient of the line connecting the initial and final velocities.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ x-intercept
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ y-intercept
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Area under the graph
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For option A, the gradient of the line connecting the starting and ending velocities gives the average acceleration.
For option B, x-intercept represents the time of when velocity is zero, therefore is incorrect.
For option C, y-intercept represents the velocity when the time is zero, therefore is incorrect.
For option D, area under the graph is the displacement, which is the correct answer.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A ball rolls horizontally off the edge of the top of a cliff. It hits the ground at a distance 2.0 m horizontally away from the base of the cliff with a vertical speed of 20 m s$^{-1}$. What is the height of the cliff?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 20 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 40 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 60 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 80 m
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Only the vertical motion needs to be considered here.


- $v^2=u^2+2as$

There is initially no vertical velocity so $u=0$


- $v^2=2gs$
- $20^2 = (2)(10)(s)$
- $s = \dfrac{400}{(2)(10)}$
- $s = 20$ m

Note that for multiple choice questions it is normally appropriate to use 10 m s$^{-2}$ as the acceleration of freefall.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
A basketball is launched at an angle and undergoes projectile motion. Air resistance is negligible. Which of the following is correct for the direction of its velocity vector and its acceleration vector at the highest point of its trajectory?

Direction of velocity vectorDirection of acceleration vector$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$horizontalno acceleration$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$no velocityno acceleration$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$no velocitydownward$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$horizontaldownward
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At the top of its trajectory, vertical velocity will be zero, but the horizontal component of the velocity will maintain the same value throughout the motion, therefore velocity will be horizontal.
Acceleration due to gravity is always acting and acts downward.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A pilot intends to fly a plane from point $A$ to point $B$. Due to strong winds, she points the nose of the plane in the direction shown by the vector $P$. Which of the choices below best represents the direction of the wind encountered by the plane?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1cb9a019-db89-4b10-8f9e-9dac8a8183a9/images/6b59fb75-dab4-4535-90b1-4fd3b6997647/PH0259-1.png)


A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1cb9a019-db89-4b10-8f9e-9dac8a8183a9/images/970c4080-cf2f-4d6f-a53f-d961d6e55fc0/PH0259A.png)

$\hspace{2cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1cb9a019-db89-4b10-8f9e-9dac8a8183a9/images/6259008a-d9d1-4035-ad36-22c3db14d45f/PH0259B.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1cb9a019-db89-4b10-8f9e-9dac8a8183a9/images/f6e5292a-e3c0-4b97-af61-b77618ebcf26/PH0259C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1cb9a019-db89-4b10-8f9e-9dac8a8183a9/images/40d2ffbc-bf44-423b-8616-4cac9e44b98a/PH0259D.png)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In order for the plane to travel from $A$ to $B$, the resultant vector of the sum of the wind vector and the vector of the orientation of the plane must point in the same direction as the vector from $A$ to $B$, as shown in the diagram below. For any of the other choices, the resultant will not be in the direction $A$ to $B$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1cb9a019-db89-4b10-8f9e-9dac8a8183a9/images/abdd4da8-6c9f-47d5-9e5f-8ac2e94d1aec/PH0259aaa.png)

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of $1.5$ m above the ground. What is the maximum height reached above the ground if the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s$^{-1}$?  (Take $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$)


- A. $\hspace{1em} 0.45$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em} 1.50$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em} 1.95$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em} 6.00$ m
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1: 
Maximum height occurs when the final speed $v$ is zero. The height reached above hand


- $\begin{aligned}
  \ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
  \ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
  \ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
  \end{aligned}$

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

Solution 2: 
Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion


- $\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh$
- $\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h$
- $h=0.45$ m

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The take off speed of a passenger aircraft is 75.0 m s$^{-1}$. A plane starts from rest and accelerates at a steady rate of 1.25 m s$^{-2}$. Which of the following correctly states the minimum duration of the acceleration, and the minimum length of the runway needed for the take off?

Duration of accelerationLength of the runway$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}$ $\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}$ $\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}$ $\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}$ $\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $a = \dfrac{v-u}{t}$
- $\hspace{2em} \Rightarrow t = \dfrac{v-u}{a} = \dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}-0}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}} = \dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}$
- $v^2 = u^2 + 2as $
- $\hspace{2em} \Rightarrow s = \dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a} = \dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2-0^2}{2(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})} = \dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{2(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The diagram shows the path of a football kicked from the ground.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/77913ebb-9bae-4e51-930d-46be726c3b93/images/38a80183-388d-4a4e-ba55-7b1ef3d0ed2c/Screenshot%202025-03-24%20at%205.29.42%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


Air resistance is negligible. Which of the arrows $A$, $B$, $C$, or $D$ represent the direction of the acceleration of the ball at the instant in time shown?
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In the absence of air resistance, gravity is the only force acting on the object so its acceleration acts downwards towards the centre of the Earth.
The vertical velocity of the ball is decreasing whilst its horizontal velocity remains the same.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
The graph shows the variation with time $t$ of the velocity $v$ of a car traveling along a straight and level road.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8fe007ab-df26-45df-b753-411208960677/images/9e41ef7e-8f69-4c96-baf0-46f791334376/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%208.45.48%E2%80%AFAM.png)


What time does it take for the car to travel a distance of 31.5 m from $t$ = 0?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 2 s
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 7 s
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 10 s
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 12 s
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Displacement is the area under the graph of velocity-time. Breaking the shape into several areas up to time 7 s:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8fe007ab-df26-45df-b753-411208960677/images/fd1b15a0-72ef-4bd7-b637-42b0a9e93f11/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%208.59.10%E2%80%AFAM.png)





- Area = $\dfrac{1}{2}(2)(4) + (5)(4) + \dfrac{1}{2}(5)(3) = 31.5$ m

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of velocity $v$ with time $t$ of a car.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9458b204-64a8-4fd2-a4e3-610338c08910/images/755ea518-7317-4796-9011-b76e19865247/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.41.51%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Consider the following quantities:


- I.DisplacementII.AccelerationIII.Change in velocity

Assuming there were numerical values on the axes, which of the following could be deduced from the graph?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in velocity can be read from the vertical axis.
The area under the line gives the displacement.
Acceleration can be deduced from the gradient of the graph.
Therefore, all statements are correct and the answer is D.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
A ball is projected with an initial speed of 2 m s$^{-1}$ making an angle of $35\degree$ with the horizontal as shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d1db62fc-049a-4a0f-ba9b-6c2f0e82f8ac/images/8864092b-ddfd-4430-a909-8d311ba38b9d/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.06.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Which expression gives the vertical component of the velocity vector?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $2$ m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $2\cos(35\degree)$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $2\sin(35\degree)$ m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $2\tan(35\degree$) m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d1db62fc-049a-4a0f-ba9b-6c2f0e82f8ac/images/2442bd62-e544-4a08-80f8-8ad91c8d4918/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.06.37%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)




- $\sin(35\degree) = \dfrac{v_y}{2}$

Therefore


- $v_y = 2\sin(35\degree)$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
An object moves 9 m east, then 12 m north.
What is the magnitude of the total displacement of this object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 3 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 21 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 36 m
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Through vector addition,
Displacement = $\sqrt{12^2+9^2}=$ 15 m
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e50b399f-ba85-45b3-9d7a-2d74e67e1d12/images/dc7fbbc7-404a-4ee4-a92a-16430a6afe38/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.15.26%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
A car moves clockwise in a circular path as shown. The direction of its instantaneous velocity at two different times is shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/21aa0775-c02f-42e9-9634-13951995f288/PH0496.png)


Which of the following vectors shows the direction of the change in velocity?
A.$\hspace{3cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/88b7624f-0886-4115-8256-99af940a2b46/PH0496A.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/85315f05-4867-40f4-be2d-ccc71a187238/PH0496B.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/7fa46ed6-98b1-4454-aee3-ef279b9768b9/PH0496C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/675b5d83-2283-4319-be39-7fd0e6705a2d/PH0496D.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in velocity = final velocity - initial velocity = $v_2 + (-v_1)$. In a vector diagram, we represent $-v_1$ as in the opposite direction to the $v_1$ direction, and then add the vectors $v_2$ and  $(-v_1)$ as shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/d52701ff-7d73-457d-a85d-d5d2fb5dd7fe/PH0496-1.png)

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The graph below shows how the acceleration of an object $a$ varies with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/225978ea-87fb-406a-9dc7-0b898236dcf3/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.16.39%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the change in speed of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $7.0$ m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $28.0$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $42.0$ m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $56.0$ m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in speed is the magnitude of the area under an acceleration-time graph.
To find the area under the graph we can split it into two sections.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/7a3ccd6a-bb00-4cc1-bb74-81d58abd51b8/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.17.41%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Section 1 is a rectangle. Area $=(4)(7)=28$ m s$^{-1}$
Section 2 is a triangle. Area $= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(7)=14$ m s$^{-1}$
Total area $= 28+14=42$ m s$^{-1}$
$\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}$
This can also be done in one step using the area of a trapezium $A=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+4)(7)=42$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: - Define distance. [1] - An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distance d with time t is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/ec0aad4a-2afd-42a6-8ebe-1a8af181242f/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.47.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - Describe the motion of the object between $t=0.5$ s and $t=1.0$ s. [1] - Calculate the instantaneous speed of the object at $t=0.5$ s. [2] - On the axes below, sketch a possible graph of the variation of velocity $v$ of the object with time $t$. There is no need to add values to the axes. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/c787d9d0-d867-4d03-980d-27f4c5fbad95/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.50.32%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Determine the direction of the change in momentum of the object during the motion. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Length of the path followed $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - Slows down/decelerates $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The slope of the graph gives the speed of the object. The slope decreases between $t=0.5$ s and  $t=1.0$ s. Therefore the object slows down.
    
  - Any evidence for drawing tangent at $t=0.5\, s$ $\checkmark$
    $\ll\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=\gg18\pm2\, m\,s^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/db214a2c-2e68-4bce-8a9a-e0cd2cc8719c/Screenshoot%202025-07-02%20at%202.52.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


    The gradient of the tangent line =$\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=18$ m s$^{-1}$
    
  - A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient $\checkmark$
    Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/4ba5e265-a440-45f1-81d9-62bf89b670e0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.30.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.
    The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.
    
  - The final momentum is less than the initial momentum $\checkmark$
    Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentum $p_f$ is less than the initial $p_i$ momentum. The change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    
    
    - $\Delta p=p_f-p_i$

    since $p_i$ > $p_f$, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
A projectile is fired at an angle above the horizontal on the surface of Moon. Which of the following statements is correct about its motion:


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The magnitude of the horizontal component of its velocity remains unchanged until it falls on the surface of the moon.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The magnitude of the vertical component of its velocity remains unchanged until it falls on the surface of the moon.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The magnitude of the horizontal component of its velocity decreases steadily until it falls on the surface of the moon.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The magnitude of the vertical component of its velocity decreases steadily until it falls on the surface of the moon.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The moon has no atmosphere. As there is no air drag, there's no change in the horizontal component of velocity. It does not decrease (making option C incorrect, and option A correct).
The magnitude of vertical component decreases only while the projectile moves upwards. At its maximum height, the vertical component becomes zero and then starts increasing in the in the downward direction until it hits ground (making D incorrect).
Option B is obviously incorrect as moon's gravitation keeps changing the vertical component.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
A football player kicks a ball initially at rest. The ball reaches a speed of 36 km h$^{-1}$ in a time of 0.5 s. Which of the following is the acceleration of the ball in terms of the gravitational acceleration, $g$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.2$g$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$g$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$g$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 7$g$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Converting 36 km h$^{-1}$ to m s$^{-1}$:


- 36 km h$^{-1}=\dfrac{36000\ \ce{m}}{3600\ \ce{s}} = 10\ \ce{ m s}^{-1}$

Acceleration is $\dfrac{\textrm{change\ in\ velocity}}{\textrm{change\ in\ time}}$
therefore


- $a=\dfrac{10}{0.5} = 20$  m s$^{-2}$

Approximating $g$ to be 10 m s$^{-2}$, the correct answer is  $2g$.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
A projectile is fired with a launch angle $\alpha$ above the horizontal and an initial velocity of 40 m s$^{-1}$ towards a cliff that rises 300 m above the plane of projection. The cliff is 120 m from the launch point.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3d210b9b-f50a-48ce-9367-d35162b07fed/images/3f8abcc5-dad8-4b7d-bdff-d4613bec5cb3/PH0132yyy.png)


Assuming that air resistance has no effect on the motion, then the time of flight taken by the projectile to reach the cliff is given by


- A. $\hspace{1em} t = 3$ s
- B. $\hspace{1em}t = 7.5$ s
- C. $\hspace{1em}t = \dfrac{4}{\cos\alpha} $ s
- D. $\hspace{1em}t = \dfrac{3}{\cos\alpha}$ s
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Time is determined from the horizontal motion


- $u_x=40\cos\alpha$
- $x = u_xt=(40 \cos\alpha)t$
- $120=(40\cos\alpha)t$
- $t = \dfrac{3}{\cos\alpha}$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
A cargo container is released from an airplane. A parachute is opened remotely a few seconds later to land it safely. Which graph shows the variation of the vertical acceleration $a$ with time $t$ for the cargo container from when it leaves the plane until landing?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/008093a4-5c1e-419d-865d-2fad91185b6a/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.24%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/b3a16c1d-d1dc-48dd-832f-9535acc8b644/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/e5911411-0db3-4109-bfcf-712ac30be345/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.50%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/3bf1ed62-d84b-4b48-a897-cdec1945761d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The cargo starts with large negative (downward) acceleration. As the cargo container falls, it is speeding up; as it is speeding up, drag force increases, so the acceleration decreases until the cargo container reaches a terminal speed where acceleration is zero. After the parachute is opened, drag force will increase, which is greater than the weight of the cargo container, causing an opposite, upwards, acceleration (deceleration). As the cargo container slows down the drag force decreases, so the net force decreases, and acceleration decreases again until the cargo container reaches a lower terminal speed where acceleration is zero and the forces are balanced.

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
A student throws a ball with an initial velocity in the horizontal direction. Air resistance is negligible. At $t = 2.0$ s, the ball has travelled a distance $x$ in the horizontal direction and a distance $y$ in the vertical direction.
What are the horizontal and vertical distances covered at $t = 1.0$ s, in terms of $x$ and $y$?

Horizontal distanceVertical distance$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{2}$ $\dfrac{y}{4}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{2}$ $\dfrac{y}{2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{4}$ $\dfrac{y}{2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{x}{4}$ $\dfrac{y}{4}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Horizontal velocity is constant, therefore, the distance travelled will be half in half the time.
Vertical height is proportional to $t^2$ ($s=\dfrac{1}{2}at^2$) therefore if time is divided by 2, height will be divided by $2^2$ = 4.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
The graph below shows the variation of velocity $v$ of an object with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/598f45bc-b927-4318-9ee6-114bb565f958/images/78e1b083-d0b4-4a47-a2cf-315152e7c88b/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.40.53%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Which of the following graphs shows how the displacement
$s$ of the object, varies with $t$?

A.$\hspace{2cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/598f45bc-b927-4318-9ee6-114bb565f958/images/c8925a05-3b10-486e-9912-0efb09937cd8/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.41.03%E2%80%AFAM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/598f45bc-b927-4318-9ee6-114bb565f958/images/8fd5614a-a39b-4e24-8115-2ae39b267f50/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.41.09%E2%80%AFAM.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/598f45bc-b927-4318-9ee6-114bb565f958/images/34179597-7e86-46a7-86f4-2f28991c1768/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.41.14%E2%80%AFAM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/598f45bc-b927-4318-9ee6-114bb565f958/images/fe72ff26-3733-4ad4-a4be-a0d64e5f90b3/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.41.21%E2%80%AFAM.png)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The area under a velocity-time graph is displacement. Both velocity and displacement are vectors so can be negative.
The graph in the question shows an object changing direction – (from the symmetry of the graph in the question we can see that) the negative and positive areas under the graph are equal in magnitude. This tells us the object must have returned to its initial position so we can disregard A and D.
Graph C represents an object travelling at a constant positive velocity and switching to an equal and opposite negative velocity halfway through its journey.
Therefore, the answer is B.
(Note for those familiar with calculus: The graph in the question shows $\cos (t)$ between 0 and $\pi$. The correct answer shows $\int \cos(t)$ $dx$ = $\sin (t)$ between 0 and $\pi$.)

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
A train, initially at rest, accelerates steadily at $1.0$ m s$^{-2}$. The distance $s$ travelled during each successive second, for the first five seconds of its motion, was recorded in meters. Which of the following correctly represents the distance covered in each successive second?
(Diagram is not to scale)

$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/a83f3eae-d161-4a41-9f8f-d22606e464ef/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.18%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/386b2086-8e1c-4e9e-bf4a-6231d750be7b/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.23%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/fc9e005d-60a8-4f17-a00f-1e4d7de3be39/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.28%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{3.5em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5bba360-5130-4997-81c9-12cafddafa67/images/c2df3d3a-dfd6-4210-ae9f-73009dd848b2/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.26.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since the question requires values of distance and provides values of initial velocity, acceleration and time, use a suitable kinematics equation to determine the distance travelled from 0 - 1 s, 0 - 2 s, 0 - 3 s, 0 - 4 s, and 0 - 5 s.
Then find the distance travelled during each second by subtraction (Subtract distance traveled in first second from distance traveled on first two seconds, etc.)
Compare your values of distance for each second with the choices given to determine the most suitable choice.
1$^{\textrm{st}}$ second: $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(1)(1)^2 = 0.5$ m
Time 0 to 2: $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(1)(2)^2 = 2$ m (distance traveled 1.5 m)

list.title: Question 23
list.content: - - Define acceleration. [1] - A car is moving on a straight road. The variation of the car's velocity $v$ with time $t$ is seen in the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/89d74bbe-f554-4361-83e3-86838d4d2316/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.18.30%E2%80%AFAM.png) Describe, in terms of acceleration, the motion of the car. [2] - A truck with a speed of 20 m s$^{-1}$ passes by a stationary car. The car starts to move with an acceleration of 4 m s$^{-2}$ just as the truck goes past. Both of the vehicles move in the same direction. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/a2c4a308-86fe-4749-8457-388fdd6baf59/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.20.52%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - Show that the time needed for the car to overtake the truck is 10 s. [3] - On the graph below, draw the variation in speed $v$ of both vehicles with time $t$ during the first 10 seconds of the motion and comment about the areas under the graphs without calculation. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/244e46d9-6793-400d-a64e-03bc982e8300/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.43.13%E2%80%AFPM.png) - In an accident scene, skid marks of a car stretching 100 m are found. According to the manufacturer of the car's tires, the deceleration that the car experiences with skidding tires is 5 m s$^{-2}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/38dc3d97-3a12-41d5-bb01-27933fb461a2/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.35.58%E2%80%AFAM.png) Determine whether the car exceeded the speed limit of 72 km h$^{-1}$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Rate of change of velocity $\checkmark$
  - Accelerates at an increasing rate/increasing acceleration $\checkmark$
    Accelerates at a constant rate/constant acceleration $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The gradient of the velocity-time graph shows the acceleration of the car. Initially, the slope increases. Then the steepness of the graph is constant. Therefore, acceleration of the car increases initially then it is constant.
    

- 
  - Use of $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ for the car $\checkmark$
    Equating distances covered by both vehicles $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\ll s = 2t^2 = 20t \gg$
    - $\ll t^2 = 10t \gg$
    - $t =$ 10 s $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
Since they are at the same position initially, the car has to cover the same distance as the truck in the same time interval. The car accelerates uniformly which enables us to employ suvat equations. The distance travelled by car for a time of $t$;
    
    
    - $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ where $u = 0$ and $a = 4$ m s$^{-2}$

    Therefore;
    
    
    - $s = \dfrac{1}{2} (4)t^2 = 2t^2$

    The truck moves at a constant speed. Hence, its distance for the time of $t$;
    
    
    - $s = vt$
    - $s = 20t$

    When both of the distances are equated;
    
    
    - $s = 2t^2 = 20t$
    - $t^2 = 10t$
    - $t = 10$ $s$

  - Straight line $\checkmark$
    Starts from (0,0) and ends at (10,40) $\checkmark$
    Horizontal line starts from (0,20) and ends at (10,20) $\checkmark$
    $\ll$ area under the graph of speed time gives distance travelled by the vehicles. Since $\gg$ they cover the same distance in 10 s according to 2 b (i)   and areas are equal/same $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/8c8caf0f-b37e-434c-86be-355597421efd/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.45.25%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The slope of a speed-time graph of an object moving in one direction is acceleration. Since the car travels with a constant acceleration, the slope of the graph should be constant. Therefore, the graph should be a straight line. The car starts from rest and its speed at $t=10$ s can be found by;
    
    
    - $v=u+at$ where $u=0$, $a=4$ m s$^{-1}$ and $t=10$ s
    - $v=0+(4)(10)=40$ m s$^{-1}$

    The speed of the truck does not change and it moves at 20 m s$^{-1}$. Its graph should be a horizontal line which has a y-intercept of 20.
    The areas under the graphs of speed-time equal to the distance covered by the vehicles. Since both of the vehicles travelled the same distance in 10 seconds according to the previous part of the question, the areas should be the same.
    

- Use of $2as=u^2$ $\checkmark$
  $u=31.6$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  Conversion of $72$ km h$^{-1}$ to $20$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  $30$ m s$^{-1} > 20$ m s$^{-1}$ and yes $\ll$ it exceeds $\gg$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The speed before pushing the brakes can be found by;
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$ where $v=0$, $a=-5$  m s$^{-2}$ and $s=100$ m

  Substitute given values in the equation;
  
  
  - $0 = u^2 + (2)(-5)(100)$
  - $0 = u^2 - 1000$
  - $1000 = u^2$
  - $u = 31.62$ m s$^{-1}$

  To compare with the speed limit, the unit of speed limit should be converted to m s$^{-1}$ or the initial speed should be converted to km h$^{-1}$
  
  
  - $\dfrac{\textrm{72 km}}{\textrm{1 h}} = \dfrac{\textrm{72000 m}}{\textrm{3600 s}} = 20$ m s$^{-1}$

  Since 31.62 m s$^{-1}$ > 20 m s$^{-1}$ the car exceeds the speed limit.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
A small object is fired horizontally at a speed of 300 m s$^{-1}$ from the top of a building. Air resistance is negligible. The object lands 900 m from the base of the building. What is the height of the building?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 34 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 44 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 88 m
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Calculate the time taken for the bullet to land


- Speed = $\dfrac{\textrm{distance}}{\textrm{time}} \Rightarrow \textrm{time} = \dfrac{\textrm{distance}}{\textrm{speed}} \Rightarrow \dfrac{900}{300}$ = 3 s

For the vertical motion, u = 0 m s$^{-1}$, a = g = 9.81 m s$^{-2}$ , t = 3 s
Using the uniform acceleration equation:


- $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$
- $s = 0 + \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(9.81)(3)^2$
- $s = 44$ m

Note that using $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$  here gives an answer of 45 m, with the closest answer being $44$ m.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: The graph shows how the speed v of a car varies with time t. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39bef262-a62a-4d85-baac-207456cf9093/images/fe6ad622-3858-44f9-a2c1-5a9d34a15873/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%205.18.15%E2%80%AFPM.png) - State the difference between average and instantaneous accelerations. [2] - Calculate the instantaneous acceleration of the car at $t=1.0$ s. [2] - Determine, with explanation, whether the car covers more distance before or after the car reaches a constant speed. [5]
list.markScheme:
- Average acceleration is the change in velocity over a period of time $\checkmark$
  Instantaneous acceleration is the acceleration at a particular instant/time/point in space $\checkmark$



- Reference to the gradient of the graph = instantenous acceleration $\checkmark$
  $7.9\pm0.5\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at the interested time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn. To do this, we draw a line that represents the gradient of the curve at the exact moment when $t=1$ s. Note that this line needs to be estimated by eye, and the mark scheme will normally have an allowed range of values to account for different answers.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39bef262-a62a-4d85-baac-207456cf9093/images/304dcb46-f0c9-4a4a-a1e9-9844c3f8479d/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%205.21.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)


  The gradient of the tangent line $= \dfrac{\textrm{rise}}{\textrm{run}}=\dfrac{26.0-11.0}{1.9-0}=7.9\textrm{ m s}^{-2}$
  
- Time of reaching constant speed = 2.7 or 2.8 s $\checkmark$
  Any evidence of distance covered = area under the line $\checkmark$
  The distance covered at constant speed  $= \ \ll(25.0)(5.0-2.8)=\ \gg$ 55$\ \ll\textrm{m}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  Accept 58 m
  Any sensible estimate of the area to determine displacment before reaching a constant speed $\checkmark$
  After $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The car reaches the constant speed of $25.0$ m s$^{-1}$ at $t=2.8$ s. This is the point where the graph becomes horizontal. The area under the speed-time graph equals the car's distance travelled. The distance $d_1$ while moving at non-constant speed can be found by the method of small square approximation.
  The area of one small square =$(1.0\ \ce{m s}^{-1})(0.1 \ce{s}) = 0.1\textrm{ m}$  and the number of small squares $= 524$
  $d_1=\left(524\right)\left(0.1\right)=52.4\ $m
  The distance $d_2$ at a constant speed 
$d_2=(25)(5.0-2.8)=55$ m
  $d_2$ > $d_1$  therefore, the cover covers more distance after reaching the constant speed.

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
An object is moving in a straight line. The graph shows the variation of the velocity $v$ of the object with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9c89cf28-1ed7-42b7-a459-43d3f38fd733/images/346ccd81-3ae2-4296-9d59-33ebd8a889f0/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.18.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Consider the following statements about the graph:


- I.At point A, the object changes its direction.II.At point C the object is at rest.III.The magnitude of the acceleration at point D is greater than at point B.

Which of the statements is/are correct?


- A. I only
- B. II only
- C. I and II only
- D. II and III only
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The slope of the velocity time graph gives the acceleration of the object. Therefore, at points A and D, there is no acceleration due to zero gradient. At point B, there is a negative acceleration.
Additionally, the velocity of the object at point C is as it aligns with the horizontal axis where $v=0$.
Hence, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
The position of a body is located with a motion detector at constant time intervals.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/4523ec09-371e-4044-b6a2-634d2ff59d9d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.46.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The distance between two successive positions of the body is given in terms of a constant $d$. Which of the following graphs could be the variation of velocity $v$ of the body with time t?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/429f4e5c-e13b-4859-b099-01b95cdf2892/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.48.31%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/05c8a817-ebf0-4301-8f2e-33cc1378af2a/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.48.36%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/e9817f1e-ce28-436c-be5a-c364ef40ec5f/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2010.36.48%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/32ed2a9b-2db9-40b5-ae99-7e2cb82907bc/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.48.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Even though the instantaneous speed of the body is unknown, average speeds for each interval can be compared by using the distances covered for the same time interval. Initially, its average speed increases then stay constant and finally decreases. Also, the object does not change direction, therefore it does not have negative velocity.  The only graph that satisfies these conditions is C.

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
An object is thrown vertically upwards at the edge of a cliff at height $h$ above the ground. When the object passes the edge of the cliff while falling downwards, a second, identical object is released from rest. Air resistance is negligible. What increases for the second object as the two objects fall?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Acceleration
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Distance from the ground
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Velocity relative to the object released earlier
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Distance from the object released earlier
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For options A & C, the accelerations of both objects are gravitational acceleration and constant, therefore the velocity difference is constant and both options are incorrect.
For option B, the object released later was released from rest and so the distance from the ground decreases. Therefore, B is incorrect.
For option D, the relative velocity of the two objects is constant because the acceleration for both objects is the same, therefore the distance between the two objects will increase and it is the correct option. In other words, the first object will always be moving faster than the second object, so the distance between them will increase.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
The variation of displacement of a trolley with time $t$ is shown on the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/381e52d4-b416-43d1-8298-afc914f8d8d6/images/a3d7bf4b-5d3c-4df4-a4ca-0358b442555b/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.57.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The magnitudes of the instantaneous velocities of the trolley at times $t_1$  and $t_2$ are $v_1$  and $v_2$ respectively. Which of the following correctly compares the instantaneous velocities with the magnitude of the average velocity of the trolley for the whole of the motion shown?

$v_1$ $v_2$A.Greater than the average velocityGreater than the average velocityB.Greater than the average velocityLess than the average velocityC.Less than the average velocityGreater than the average velocityD.Less than the average velocityLess than the average velocity
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The magnitudes of instantaneous velocities can be found from the gradient of the graph at the corresponding points. The average velocity is the total displacement over time and it is mathematically equal to the slope of a straight line that connects points at the start and end of the motion on the graph.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/381e52d4-b416-43d1-8298-afc914f8d8d6/images/b9686814-6527-48ce-afc7-39f12f8517f7/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.02.29%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When the slopes of the lines are compared, It can be seen that
$v_2>$ average velocity $>v_1$. Therefore the answer is C.

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
A ball is released from rest at a height $h$ above the ground. At each bounce 75% of its kinetic energy is lost. Which graph represents the variation of the ball's velocity $v$ with time $t$ from the beginning of motion until the moment just before the third bounce? Assume the acceleration of the ball is in in the negative direction and that air resistance is negligible.

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/a516a5f2-3a03-4885-811d-0da67b6ad48e/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.14%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/c52e4b88-650f-407b-aa7e-ecf2ab94b5f1/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.26%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/f9d6effd-a838-49ed-b769-1e65f233ace2/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/75cb8fb0-e10e-4e0e-b129-422f1813f50d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Kinetic energy $E_k$ is directly proportional to the square of the magnitude of velocity $v$


- $E_k = \dfrac{1}{2} mv^2$

The velocity will decrease to half of its value at each bounce.
The value of the acceleration is constant, free fall acceleration $g$. The velocity time graph should be linear and all sections should have a negative gradient to represent downwards acceleration.
The direction of velocity is positive on the way up, and negative on the way down.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
A ball is released from rest and falls vertically for 3 s on Earth. Air resistance is negligible. What is the average speed of the ball during the motion?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 3 m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 30 m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1:


- $v = u + at = 0 + (10)(3) = 30$ m s$^{-1}$
- $v_{av} = \dfrac{v+u}{2} = \dfrac{30+0}{2} = 15$ m s$^{-1}$


Solution 2: 
Distance covered by the ball;


- $s = \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$

Due to absence of air resistance;


- $a = g$
- $s = \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(10)(3)^2$
- $s = 45$ m

$\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{\textrm{total distance}}{\textrm{total\ time}}$
$\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{45}{3} = 15$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 32
list.content: - State the difference between distance and displacement. [2] - A dart player throws a dart horizontally with the speed of $15$ m s$^{-1}$ to hit a dartboard. The vertical displacement of the dart is $0.35$ m. Air resistance is negligible. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/cf1e86d8-8c54-4110-8bb5-a459436d1e84/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.49.06%E2%80%AFAM.png) - Show that the time taken for the dart to reach the centre of the dartboard is approximately 0.3 s. [2] - Calculate the angle below the horizontal, in degrees, of the velocity of the dart as it hits the dartboard. [3] - Determine the displacement of the dart. [2] - On the axes below, sketch how the square of the velocity $v^2$ of the dart varies with the square of time $t^2$. [2] (no need to add values on the axes) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/78c0e156-6b74-4420-b9b1-ae0f2408d349/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.49.33%E2%80%AFAM.png)
list.markScheme:
- Distance is the length of the path followed while displacement is the change in position $\checkmark$
  Distance is a scalar quantity while displacement is a vector quantity $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - Use of $t = \sqrt{\dfrac{2s}{a}}$
    
    
    - OR

    Use of $v = \sqrt{2as}$ and $t = \dfrac{v}{a}$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $t =  \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(0.35)}{9.81}} $ =        0.27 s $\checkmark$ (extra significant figures must be shown for MP2)

    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The initial velocity of the dart has no vertical component and accelerates due to gravity on the vertical axis. Therefore, the time of motion in the vertical axis can be found by following the suvat equation;
    
    
    - $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ where $u=0$, $a=9.81$ m s$^{-2}$ and $s=0.35$ m

    After substituting the values;
    
    
    - $0.35 = \dfrac{1}{2} (9.81 )t^2$

    By rearranging;
    
    
    - $t = \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(0.35)}{9.81}} = 0.27$ s

    
  - vertical velocity $= 0 + (9.81)(0.27) =2.6$ m s$^{-1}$
$\checkmark$
    horizontal velocity $= 15$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    $\tan\, \theta = \dfrac{2.6}{15}$  giving   $\theta$ = 10° $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The horizontal component of the velocity of the dart is constant. Therefore, the horizontal component of velocity at the instant of reaching the dartboard is $15$ m s$^{-1}$.
    The vertical component of velocity can be found by the following equation;
    
    
    - $v=u+at$ where $u=0$, $a=9.81$ m s$^{-2}$ and $t=0.27$ s

    By substituting known values;
    
    
    - $v=0+(9.81)(0.27)=2.6$ m s$^{-1}$

    Hence, the relationship between horizontal, vertical, and resultant velocity in terms of their directions is given as shown
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/a0034b4c-57e2-43e1-9b26-d917b9683c84/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.56.02%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    By using geometry;
    
    
    - $\tan\theta=\dfrac{2.6}{15}$  giving
$\theta=10\degree$

    
  - Horizontal displacement$=(15)(0.27)=4.05$ m $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $s = \sqrt{(s_h)^2 + (s_v)^2} = \sqrt{4.05^2 + 0.35^2}=4.1$ m $\checkmark$

    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The horizontal displacement $s_h$;
    
    
    - $s_h=u_ht$ where $u_h=15$ m s$^{-1}$ and $t = 0.27$ s
    - $s_h=(15)(0.27)=4.05$ m

    The vertical displacement $s_v$;
    
    
    - $s_v = 0.35$ m

    The resultant displacement s can be found by geometry;
    
    
    - $s = \sqrt{(s_h)^2 + (s_v)^2} = \sqrt{4.05^2 + 0.35^2} = 4.1$ m

    
  - Straight line $\checkmark$
    Non-zero y-intercept $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/fa909b24-b19a-42bd-8119-6be319b0cf3a/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.51.44%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
The velocity of the dart has two components horizontal $v_x$ and vertical $v_y$. Therefore, it is;
    
    
    - $v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + (v_y)^2}$

    Only $v_y$ changes by the following equation;
    
    
    - $v_y = at$ where $a = g$

    By substituting $a = g$ in the equation;
    
    
    - $v_y = gt$

    Replace $v_y$ with $gt$ in the previous equation;
    
    
    - $v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + (g^2t^2)}$

    By taking the square of both sides to find a relationship between $v^2$ and $t^2$;
    
    
    - $v^2 = (v_x)^2 + g^2t^2$

    Since $v^2_x$ and $g^2$ are constant, this relationship can be summarized as;
    
    
    - $y=mx+b$ where $(v_x)^2=b=\textrm{y-intercept}$ and $g^2=m=\textrm{slope}$

    Both of the values are positive. Therefore; the graph should be a straight line with a positive gradient and positive y-intercept.

list.title: Question 33
list.content: - Define displacement. [1] - A table tennis ball is thrown horizontally from the top of a building. The variation of the ball's horizontal displacement $s$ with time $t$ is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/932d427e-605f-47fa-a5d8-e41a7a57f1aa/images/7db361d2-b344-4fb2-acd3-5e3319252613/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%205.40.560%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - State which quantity is given by the gradient of the tangent to the graph at any time during the motion. [1] - On the graph below, sketch the expected variation of horizontal displacement with time when air resistance is ignored. The original curve is given as a dashed line. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/932d427e-605f-47fa-a5d8-e41a7a57f1aa/images/2ffe11d8-4617-4469-93e0-583cde8b2c64/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%205.46.15%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - A stone is then launched with a horizontal speed of $20$ m s$^{-1}$ from a height of $12$ m above the ground. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/932d427e-605f-47fa-a5d8-e41a7a57f1aa/images/a4e7df5e-9deb-4191-a72c-177e53af9864/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%205.49.06%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) Determine the magnitude of the displacement of the stone when it hits the ground if air resistance is considered to be negligible. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Change in position OR straight line distance and direction between the starting and finishing points of journey $\checkmark$



- 
  - $\underline{\textrm{Horizontal}}$ velocity $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of a displacement-time graph at any point gives the velocity of the object at that instant.
  - $\hspace{1em}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/932d427e-605f-47fa-a5d8-e41a7a57f1aa/images/a1d96464-c216-400c-85b7-980fcb620c52/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%205.51.01%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


    A straight line passing through the origin $\checkmark$
    Gradient matches starting gradient of curve $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Due to the absence of air resistance, the horizontal resultant force on the stone will be zero. This results in zero acceleration. Therefore, the horizontal velocity will be constant. It can be represented by a straight line where the gradient matches the initial horizontal velocity of the object.
    

- The time needed to reach ground = 1.$6$ s $\checkmark$
  Horizontal displacement = $\ll(20)(1.6)= \gg 31\ \ll\textrm{m}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  Displacement of the stone= $\sqrt{{12}^2+{31}^2}$ $\checkmark$
  $s=$  34 m $\checkmark$ (33 m also accepted here)
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Due to the absence of air resistance, the stone accelerates vertically due to gravity and the horizontal velocity of the stone is constant. The time $t$ taken to reach the ground can be found by
  $\begin{aligned}
   s &= ut+\frac{1}{2}at^2\\
   -12 &= 0(t)+(\frac{1}{2})(-9.81)t^2\\
   t^2 &= 2.4\\
   t &= 1.56\textrm{ s} \\
   \end{aligned}$
  Therefore, the horizontal displacement $s_h$ of the stone:
  
  
  - $s_h=vt=\left(20\right)\left(1.56\right)=31$ m

  The magnitude of the vertical displacement $s_v$ is $12$ m. Finding the magnitude of the displacement s of the stone:
  $\begin{aligned}
   \hspace{1.8em} s^2 &= (s_v)^2+(s_h)^2\\
   s^2 &= {12}^2+{31}^2\\
   s &= 33\ or\ 34\, \ce{m}
   \end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
A projectile is launched horizontally on Earth with initial speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$ from a height of $5.0$ m above the ground.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/adca8fcd-c774-446b-a421-eb944e4ddd54/images/51e584df-f2d9-4096-bc80-662140961015/PH0851aaaa.png)


What is the magnitude of the displacement of the stone when it reaches the ground?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $5.0$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $8.0$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{34}$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{51}$ m
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For the time, analyzing the vertical direction
$\hspace{1em}$ $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$
$\hspace{1em}$ $5 = \dfrac{1}{2}(10)t^2$
$\hspace{1em}$ $t = 1$ s
The horizonal displacement is
$\hspace{1em}$ $\Delta x = u_x t = (3)(1) = 3$ m
The vertical displacement from the diagram is $5$ m.
The net displacement is


- Displacement $=\sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{34}$ m

list.title: Question 35
list.content: In an experiment, the free-fall of a ball bearing is used to measure the acceleration due to gravity. The ball bearing is suspended with an electromagnet. Then it is released from a height of $h$ above a table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/b0277bbd-a6fc-4971-907d-53ec8cd7191f/PH0511_A.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]}}$ The time t needed for the ball bearing to reach the ground after release is measured. The experiment is repeated for different values of $h$. The theoretically predicted relationship between time t and h is $t^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}$ - State why there is a need to collect data for a range of values of $h$ to verify this relationship. [1] - The experimental data for $t^2$ and h are plotted on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/be791221-65d1-438f-8aba-c562a49fd9e8/Screenshot%202025-04-16%20at%209.01.00%E2%80%AFAM.png) - Draw the line of best fit for the plotted data on the graph. [1] - Suggest whether the data is consistent with the theoretical prediction. [2] - By using the line of best fit, determine a value for g and state the units. [4] - The theoretical relationship is for an object falling in a vacuum. - Compare the experimental result to the accepted value of g and suggest a reason for the discrepancy. [2] - State and explain whether the source of error in (c)(i) is a systematic or random error. [2]
list.markScheme:
- To prove the relationship between $t^2$ and h different values are needed to find a trend
  OR
  to reduce random error $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To prove a relationship, one piece of data is not enough. The relationship can be generalized by using a graph where multiple points can reveal a trend. More data allows for drawing a graph that can support the relationship. Additionally, using more data and taking the average of them reduces the amount of random error.



- 
  - A straight line with roughly equal numbers of points above and below the line $\checkmark$

  
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/e907ca39-4906-4c19-acce-6de827b937d7/Screenshot%202025-04-16%20at%209.01.10%E2%80%AFAM.png)


  
  - $\ll$ According to the theory $\gg$  $t^2$ is proportional to $h$ OR ${t^2}\propto\ h$ $\checkmark$
    A best-fit line that is a straight line that passes through the origin can be drawn $\checkmark$
    $\ll$  Yes $\gg$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the predicted relationship;
    
    
    - $t^2\propto h$

    This relationship suggests that the graph should be a straight line which passes through the origin. According to plotted data, that kind of straight line can be drawn.
  - Rearrangement of the formula to solve for $g$
    
    
    - $g=2\dfrac{h}{t^2}$ $\checkmark$

    Using a correct  data point on the line
    OR
    Correct calculation of  the gradient $\checkmark$
    g is between 9.0 and 9.5 $\checkmark$
    $\ce{m s}^{-2}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The given formula is
    
    
    - $t^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}$

    The gradient is therefore equal to $\dfrac{2}{g}$.
    Finding the gradient gives
    
    
    - gradient = $\dfrac{0.19}{0.9}=0.21$

    Solving for $g$:
    
    
    - $0.21 = \dfrac{2}{g}$
    - $g=\dfrac{2}{0.21}=9.5\ \ce{m s}^{-2}$





- 
  - Experimental result is lower $\checkmark$
    There is air resistance which $\ll$ will result in using exaggerated value of time in the equation $\gg$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The time t should be smaller than the measured value under the frictionless environment. According to the equation,
    
    
    - $g=2\bigg(\dfrac{h}{t^2}\bigg)$

    Therefore in the absence of air resistance, the experimental value for $\dfrac{h}{t^2}$ would be greater than the values obtained in this experiment. Therefore, the calculated value is lower than the accepted value.
  - Systematic $\checkmark$
    The result of the experiment is always less than the actual value/results are biased in one direction only $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The error is the result of the design of the experiment and leads to the results always being less than the actual value. Therefore, it is systematic.

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of speed $v$ of a ball with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13b5c41f-9e6b-4937-8397-65c5b2d2336e/images/5281444d-ae8d-4868-83f7-f80dd8085194/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.10.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The initial speed of the ball is very high. Which of the following statements could be true for the ball?


- A. It is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance.
- B. It is thrown vertically upward in the absence of air resistance.
- C. It is thrown vertically downward in the presence of air resistance.
- D. It is thrown vertically downward in the absence of air resistance.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to the graph, the ball has a decreasing deceleration and reaches terminal velocity. Since the acceleration of the ball is not constant, air resistance must be acting on the ball. Air resistance always acts in the direction opposite to the velocity.
In an upward motion, air friction and gravity are in the same direction. Therefore, it is not possible for them to cancel each other so that the ball reaches terminal velocity. It should be moving in the downward direction. Hence, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
An object is launched with an angle of $\theta$ from the ground and an initial velocity of $v$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/dbd07e55-801c-4572-895f-a7f3311a2d78/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.52.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which graph shows the variation of the horizontal component $v_h$ of the velocity of the object with time $t$? (Air resistance is not ignored)

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/122016ee-f9f7-45c0-b47a-29aae3f83c0d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.45.57%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/155655a5-993f-4307-84fe-c81857607d5d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.44.36%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/aeb0b614-67b2-47e5-82a0-d6f7ab903960/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.44.41%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/ed045a0d-bd03-4dac-a6d1-352058b23b1e/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.44.46%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The object starts its motion with non-zero horizontal velocity. Due to air resistance, It experiences negative acceleration (opposite to the direction of motion). The force from air resistance is proportional to the speed of the object. Since a decrease in speed results in a decrease in air resistance, the magnitude of negative acceleration should decrease over time. The gradient of the $v-t$ graphs indicates acceleration. The only graph that has a decreasing negative gradient is B.
Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 38
list.content: A ball of mass $1.6$ kg is dropped from a very high building. The only forces acting on the ball are the force of gravity and air resistance. The graph shows the variation of the vertical velocity $v$ of the ball with time $t$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db291db8-8a1d-4c99-bd14-40785346db3c/images/f8d68b0f-5361-4c95-a869-cad21dc827fe/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%201.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png) - - Define terminal speed. [1] - State the terminal speed of the ball. [1] - Estimate the vertical displacement of the ball during the $10.0$ s of motion. [2] - - Calculate the instantaneous acceleration of the ball at $t=2.0$ s. [2] - Determine the magnitude of the vertical component of the force of air resistance at $t=2.0$ s [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The maximum speed/velocity  obtained by an object during  motion in a fluid/gas/air/liquid $\checkmark$
  - 18 $\ll\textrm{ m s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the graph, the velocity of the ball increases and then stays constant at 18 m s$^{-1}$.
    

- Any reference to the area under the graph being equal to the displacement. $\checkmark$
  $125\pm10$ $\ll\textrm{m, downwards}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the velocity-time graph is equal to the ball's displacement. The area can be calculated by using the small square approximation. The area $A_s$ of each small square:
  
  
  - $A_s=(0.2)(1)=0.2$ m

  There are approximately 625 small   squares. Therefore, the total area A or displacement:
  
  
  - $A=(625)(0.2)=125$ m

  Note that displacement is a vector quantity and so a direction should be stated. In this case, the ball is falling so the direction of the displacement is downwards.
  
- 
  - Reference to use of the gradient of the graph to find instantaneous acceleration. $\checkmark$
    $2.8\ \pm\ 0.5$ $\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg $ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at a given time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db291db8-8a1d-4c99-bd14-40785346db3c/images/63f6af18-586a-453f-95d2-612df55c9d96/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%201.42.12%E2%80%AFPM.png)


  - $mg-ma=$ air resistance $\checkmark$
    $(1.6)(9.81)-(1.6)(2.8)=$ air  resistance $\checkmark$
    11 $\ll\textrm{N}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    ECF for the use of the answer of (c) (i) to determine the acceleration
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The vertical resultant force $F_{net}$ acting on the mass:
    
    
    - $F_{net}$ = Weight - Air Resistance

    or
    
    
    - $F_{net} = F_g - F_d$

    and
    
    
    - $F_{net}$ = $ma$

    Therefore
    
    
    - $ma = F_g - F_d$
    - $F_d = mg - ma$
    - $F_d=(1.6)(9.81)-(1.6)(2.8)$
    - $F_d = 11.3$ N

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
A stream flows east with a speed $v_s$. A boat points due south and moves with a speed $v_o$ relative to the water.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dca64207-6693-4704-9450-d31d76555a76/images/6777c4c8-7f29-491c-b3cb-82e8d91b9132/Screensho0t%202024-10-26%20at%203.57.21%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The ratio  $\dfrac{v_o}{v_s} = \dfrac{1}{2}$
Which of the following is correct about the magnitude in m s$^{-1}$ and the angle $\theta$ between the velocity of the boat and the side of the stream?

$\hspace{1em}$ Magnitude $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{2.5em}$ $\theta$ $\hspace{2.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ A. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sqrt{3}\,v_o$ $\sin^{-1}\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ B. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sqrt{3}\,v_o$ $\cos^{-1}\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ C. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sqrt{5}\,v_o$ $\tan^{-1}(2)$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ D. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sqrt{5}\,v_o$ $\tan^{-1}\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since $v_s = 2\,v_o$
The magnitude of the net velocity


- $v_{net}=\sqrt{v_o\textrm{}^2 +(2v_o)^2} = \sqrt{5} v_o$

The direction is determined by the angle it makes with the side of the river
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dca64207-6693-4704-9450-d31d76555a76/images/ca02249a-5cc8-40f5-b8ce-0401db161320/PH0492zzz2.png)




- $tan \theta = \dfrac{v_o}{2v_o} =\dfrac{1}{2}$
- $\theta = \tan^{-1}(\dfrac{1}{2})$

Thus the previous answer of $\sqrt{5} v_o$ combined with $\theta = \tan^{-1}(\dfrac{1}{2})$ corresponds to answer D.

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
A car decelerates with a constant rate until it stops.
Which graph shows the variation of speed of the car  $v$ with the distance travelled $s$?

A.$\hspace{2cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/dc6c106f-9423-4076-af71-349a76f6d49e/PH0850aa.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/ecdf9631-dbe2-4c9e-9471-91455293b072/PH0850bb.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/7012af2d-9e8a-48b5-89f7-b121537e78be/PH0850cc.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6049235-a4da-4a75-84ef-fa4f125f17a1/images/b643a4ae-9ad7-4081-851b-10148999bcbb/PH0850dd.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using https://www.geogebra.org/m/CtfF7SBc]}}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Note that this is a velocity-displacement graph, and so needs to be considered carefully.
Since


- $v^2=u^2+2as$

The car decelerates to stop


- $a$ is negative

Then


- $v^2=u^2-2as$

As the car moves slower, it takes more time to cover the same distance. The velocity changes at a constant rate. Therefore, each increment of distance has a larger and larger change in $velocity$.

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
A body is moving in a straight line with a constant acceleration of $a$. Its speed increases from $u$ to $v$ in a time of $t$. Consider the following expressions:


- I.$ut+\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}$ $\hspace{1em}$II.$vt-\dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ $\hspace{1em}$III.$\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}$

Which expression(s) can be used to determine the displacement of the body during the time interval $t$?



- A. I only
- B. II only
- C. I and II only
- D. II, and III only
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When the expression in I is simplified, it is equal to;


- $\dfrac{(v+u)t}{2}$

This is a uniform acceleration formula for displacement, where the average velocity is multiplied by the time taken.
This is included in the data booklet as the formula of displacement.
Comparing expression III to expression I, it can be seen that expression III will give a lower value than expression I. Therefore, It does not give displacement.
For expression II:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1eaa9bbe-f2f8-4aec-98be-a12855120b47/images/b5c4fc0d-f50e-49a3-a2c4-636e71ca5341/PH0540.png)


Using the above graph to analyze expression II. The area under the sloping line will give the displacement. The area of this trapezoid can be found by subtracting the area of triangle $vXu$ from the area of rectangle $OvXt$.
The area of $OvXt$ is $vt$.
The area of $vXu$ is $\frac{1}{2}(v-u)t$
We know that $v - u = at$, thereforen after substitution, the area $vXu$ is equal to $\frac{1}{2}at^2$.
Subtracting the two areas gives the expression $vt - \frac{1}{2}at^2$, which is the same as expression II.
Therefore the correct answer is C

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
A car is moving on a horizontal road. The variation of velocity $v$ of a car with time $t$ can be seen in the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/c128ba6b-fdba-4393-b947-d9b089714c52/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.07.04%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following graphs shows the variation of displacement $s$ of the car with time $t$?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/4a90d0a0-0eaa-4639-98c7-dde170216fcc/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.10.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/0f9b7151-16b9-4f2b-a529-96bdb88085f2/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.07.12%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/704ccb98-6f84-43b6-9758-5f21a22ae139/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.08.10%E2%80%AFPM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/d646c383-d001-464e-b653-e56ae8ccaf24/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.08.15%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The velocity-time graph shows that the car moves in the positive direction for half of the time, and then in the negative direction for the second half of the motion. The gradient of a displacement-time graph at any point is the velocity. Therefore, the displacement-time graph that matches this motion will have a positive gradient for the first half of the motion and a negative gradient for the second half of the motion. The only graph correctly shows this is C.

list.title: Question 43
list.content:
A stone is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance. Which of the following graphs best shows the variation of velocity $v$ of the stone with time $t$ until it reaches the maximum height above the ground?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/1372cf34-9ff4-41eb-8e1b-409b309a48d5/PH0533aa.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/7a0b7787-0fec-4f49-8e31-29ea318dae6d/PH0533bb.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/42a7ebb7-983c-4564-8c3c-7e51b7981ded/PH0533cc.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/f92baaf5-5218-4036-bc1c-47f423955d9d/PH0533dd.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
While the stone is ascending, its speed decreases due to gravitational attraction and air resistance. Although gravitational attraction is constant, air resistance decreases with speed. Therefore, the total force opposing the motion decreases. This results in a decrease in deceleration.
When the acceleration decreases, the change in velocity gets lower for a constant change in time. Thus the gradient should decrease. Additionally, the velocity of the stone must be zero when it reaches maximum height. These two conditions are satisfied in choice C.

list.title: Question 45
list.content:
At time $T=0$ object A is launched from the top of a cliff of height $h$ at a velocity $v$ and an angle of $30\text{\textdegree}$ below the horizontal. At the same time Object B is launched from the bottom of the cliff at an angle of 30$\text{\textdegree}$ above the horizontal with the same velocity $v$. The objects collide at time $T=t$.
The trajectories of the objects are shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5d099398-5385-4122-9781-2f400d31ce34/images/d833a6da-55dc-44ff-8aa2-fc53d935bf1f/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.56.33%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Air resistance is negligible. What is $t$?



- A. $\hspace{1em} $ $t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\cos(30\text{\textdegree})}$
- B. $\hspace{1em} $ $t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}$
- C. $\hspace{1em} $ $t=\dfrac{h}{v\cos(30\text{\textdegree})}$
- D. $\hspace{1em} $ $t=\dfrac{h}{v\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Both have the same horizontal velocity ($v_H=v \cos(30\text{\textdegree})$) so we may ignore the horizontal direction
(A person travelling in a car with the same horizontal velocity as the objects would only see vertical motion)
So, we must consider only the vertical equations of motion of the objects.


- $s=u\,t+\dfrac{1}{2}\,a\,t^2+initial\ position$

Let us treat the upward direction as positive and the ground to be at position $s=0$. (These choices are arbitrary – but we must be consistent)
The initial vertical velocity of object A is $-v\,\sin(\,30\text{\textdegree})$ and the initial velocity of object B is $v\,\sin( 30\text{\textdegree})$. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5d099398-5385-4122-9781-2f400d31ce34/images/68c635f9-cf33-448b-b01e-eb23c6ad08d1/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.00.26%E2%80%AFAM.png)


The position object A $s_A$ is given by
$s_A=-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2+h$ (acceleration vector points downwards so $a=-g$)
The position of object B $s_B$ is given by


- $s=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2$

We want to know when the objects collide (where the vertical positions are the same) so equating $s_A$ and $s_B$ gives.


- $-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}gt^2+h=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2$

Notice we have $-\dfrac{1}{2}gt^2$ on both sides so these cancel. There is a frame of reference in which the objects are not accelerating so acceleration is irrelevant to time of collision! (A person in freefall beside the objects would see no acceleration - they would measure $s_A=-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})+h$ and $s_B=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})$


- $-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t+h=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t$
- $h=2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t$
- $t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}$
